snippet: Painful, poignant and mostly secret, the chamber, until recently at ground zero, served as a private sanctuary and was transformed by mementos into a shrine.
abstract: Building Blocks column; Family Room, onetime private sanctuary for relatives of victims of Sept 11, 2001, terrorist attacks, has been recreated at the New York State Museum in Albany; Family Room first opened in April 2002 in building opposite ground zero, and was only accessible to victims' relatives; museum's collection includes mementos related to about 1,000 victims, roughly one-third of all causalities that day.
lead_paragraph: Painful, poignant and mostly secret, the chamber, until recently at ground zero, served as a private sanctuary and was transformed by mementos into a shrine.

headline.main: A 9/11 Shrine Where Families Mourned for Years, Now Open to Others
headline.print_headline: A 9/11 Shrine Where Families Mourned, Now Open to Others
